none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Pfeuffer, November 22, 1879
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from George Pfeuffer, November 22, 1879
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 4 Louis L. McInnis Papers
Board of Directors of the A & M College

en: Official letter from George Pfeuffer, Secretary of the Board of Directors of the Agricultural and Mechanical College in Bryan, Texas, formally notifying Professor Louis L. McInnis of the Board's November 22, 1879 resolution to accept his resignation effective at the close of the current academic term. The letter also documents the Board's concurrent resolution that adjunct professors shall not have voting rights in faculty matters. This document reflects institutional governance and personnel decisions at an early Texas agricultural college.

body.value:
Office Room of the Board of
Directors of the A & M College
Bryan Texas Novr. 22, 1879,

Prof. Louis L McInnis
Adjunct Professor of the A & M College.

Sir!
        I have the honor to inform you that at
a Meeting of the Board of Directors of the A &
M College held at Bryan Texas on the 22d
day of November A D 1879.
It was resolved
That your resignation be accepted to take effect at the
close of the present scholastic term, unless
sooner if the President of the College finds
that your services may be dispensed with.
further resolved
        That no Adjunct Professor shall have a
vote in the faculty and that the secretary
be requested to communicate the foregoing to
Prof. Louis L McInnis.

By order of the Board
George Pfeuffer
Secretary of the Board

**Alright, let's get this transcription done. Here's how I'm approaching this:**

1.  **Image Analysis:** Okay, it's a handwritten letter, dating back to 1879, sent from the A&M College Board of Directors to Professor Louis L. McInnis. It seems like it's an official notification about his resignation, plus a tidbit about Adjunct Professors not voting in the faculty. I've got the sender's office room, the date, and the recipient. All the necessary metadata.

2.  **Transcription Strategy:**
    *   **Headers:** I will start with "Office Room of the Board of Directors of the A & M College Bryan Texas Novr. 22, 1879." â€“ the abbreviation looks like "Novr.", and I will be careful on the 22nd.
    *   **Recipient:** "Prof. Louis L McInnis, Adjunct Professor of the A & M College. Sir!" I'm making sure to capture that squiggle at the end.
    *   **Body:** I'll transcribe this faithfully, capturing the formal language, and the "22<sup>d</sup>" date notation.
    *   **Resolutions:** "It was resolved" and "further resolved". I will render these as their own lines, to reflect emphasis.
    *   **Signature:** "George Pfeuffer, Secretary of the Board". Need to nail that signature, and I confirmed that George Pfeuffer was associated with the Board around this time.

3.  **Formatting:** I am using HTML tags as instructed. I need to keep line breaks. I have to be careful with "Nobr." versus "Novr." It seems "Novr." is the appropriate abbreviation. Also, the superscript "d". "A & M" with the stylized ampersand. I'll maintain line breaks. I'll also add a line break before "It was resolved", etc.

4.  **Refining Text:** I will copy the text and double check it as I transcribe it into the final output format.
    *   I'll check the "Nobr." vs. "Novr." one last time. It seems to be "Novr.". I'll keep an eye on punctuation. "Novr. 22, 1879."
    *   I am going to keep the underlining of "It was resolved" and "further resolved". Since I cannot use `<u>`, I am just going to put each phrase on its own line.
    *   The middle initial in McInnis, I'm pretty sure that's a cursive 'L'.

5.  **Final Review:** Ok, let's do a final review. Reading the document again, top to bottom. It looks like the layout. It's legible. I am set. I am going to produce the final transcription below.
